awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Formal Design of Semi-Autonomous Cyberphysical Transportation Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop fundamental theory, efficient algorithms, and realistic
experiments for the analysis and design of safety-critical cyber-physical transportation systems
with human operators. The research focuses on preventing crashes between automobiles at road
intersections, since these account for about 40% of overall vehicle crashes. Specifically, the main
objective of this work is to design provably safe driver-assist systems that understand driver?s
intentions and provide warnings/overrides to prevent collisions. In order to pursue this goal,
hybrid automata models for the driver-vehicles-intersection system, incorporating driver
behavior and performance as an integral part, are derived from human-factors experiments. A
partial order of these hybrid automata models is constructed, according to confidence levels on
the model parameters. The driver-assist design problem is then formulated as a set of partially
ordered hybrid differential games with imperfect information, in which games are ordered
according to parameter confidence levels. The resulting designs are validated experimentally in
a driving simulator and in large-scale computer simulations.

This research leverages the potential of embedded control and communication technologies to
prevent crashes at traffic intersections, by enabling networks of smart vehicles to cooperate with
each other, with the surrounding infrastructure, and with their drivers to make transportation
safer, more enjoyable, and more efficient. The work is based on a collaboration among
researchers in formal methods, autonomous control, and human factors who are studying realistic and
provably correct warning/override algorithms that can be readily transitioned to production
vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to develop the scientific information and improved test methods needed to reduce the number of crashes that occur at intersections.  In the U.S., about 40% of all crashes occur at intersections and more than 30,000 people die each year in motor vehicle crashes. 

One way to reduce those crashes is to warn drivers about other vehicles with which they may collide, especially when the light is yellow.   Current warning systems often beep to alert the driver of a hazard, but the driver must look down at the instrument panel to read the warning (“crash warning”).  Looking away from the road when a crash is likely is counterproductive.  Furthermore, the instrument panel warning does not say where to look.

This project examined presenting the warning (a red bar or yellow arrow) on the windshield and near the hazard, but not blocking what the driver needs to see.  Technically, this is referred to as a full windshield head-up display. 

To see if this really was a good idea, we completed three driving simulator experiments to collect information on how drivers approached intersections (to help determine when the warning should appear) and responded to the warning.  It was often but not always a good idea, and the concept has been modified as a consequence.

Thus, this project advanced the science of driving and provide guidance as to how a new technology warning system that will appear in future vehicles should be implemented.

A major side benefit of this research was improvement of Society of Automotive Engineers Recommended Practice J2944, which defines driving performance measures such as gap, headway, time to collision, roadway departure, etc.  For knowledge about driving to advance, we need to be using the same terms with agreed upon meanings.  A lane departure, for which there are 13 names, could be called a lane bust, lane exceedance, over the edge line, and so forth.  But even worse, terms concerning driving performance are rarely defined and definitions are inconsistent.  Does lane departure mean the vehicle is about to depart, is departing, or has departed?  Which part of the lane marking (inside edge, middle, or the outside edge) is the boundary?  Which tire (front or rear) should be considered?  Furthermore, how does count departures for a tractor-trailer going around a curve, where the cab is in, but the trailer is out. 

When studying how people or automated vehicle drive, lane departures are often counted.  But as different names are used and how departures are counted is not stated, comparing results between studies is impossible.

To solve this problem, SAE J2944 lists required names and states how each term is defined.  For most terms, there are several definitions, recognizing that what is appropriate may vary.  For example, a warning to the driver may indicate when a departure is beginning, whereas the police want to know the vehicle has left the lane so there is no debate about a citation.  To provide clarity, one needs to identify the term and the definition used (for example, lane departure, option C, as defined in SAE J2944).
